In Italy, a right-to-die case has created a constitutional crisis.

It involves a woman who has been in a coma for 17 years and Italy's prime minister, who's defying a Supreme Court ruling and trying to rush through a law that would force doctors to reconnect the woman's feeding tubes.
The Vatican has weighed in on the side of the prime minister.
NPR's Sylvia Poggioli reports from Rome.
Eluana Englaro has been in an irreversible coma since a 1992 car accident.
Last summer, her father Giuseppe Englaro won a decade-long legal battle when the highest court ruled in his favor that feeding tubes could be disconnected.

But the Catholic Church mobilized, and under government pressure, no hospital could be found willing to carry out the ruling until last week, when Englaro was transferred to a clinic in the northern city of Udine where on Friday doctors began reducing her nutrition.
Giuseppe Englaro insists his daughter would not have wanted to be kept alive artificially.
(Through translator) She has said clearly she would not want her body to be dependent on the invasive car of others, that it would be an unacceptable violation.
But Eluana has been violated.
She has undergone a therapeutic violation.
But within in hours, in an unexpected move, Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi issued an emergency decree stating that nutrition can't be suspended from any patient who depends on it.
(Through translator) She breathes.
She's alive.
She can even bear a child.
And her vegetative state might even be reversible one day.
